626B7F92691B4D9E93112055ABB3D362.description: Justify the protection of rights and responsibilities.

650F6FEC780C401CB1786039F0565A8F.description: Reflect on personal rights and responsibilities.

B30D00A6B0FE43B4A30A899A5C5A7D9B.description: Citizens in Canada have rights, freedoms, and responsibilities.

29EF28F2ECF5456CA704D584A3C32C4C.description: Citizenship in Canada carries responsibilities, such as contributing to the community, respecting the rights of others, and voting.

8245EBAF600644E59C7447E1E6003BEC.description: Citizenship in Canada provides rights, such as the right to be treated equally regardless of difference.

38FEE55A8F4F40EAA4E55A15C6791ADA.description: Learning Outcome: Students investigate rights and responsibilities in Canada.

3BF532C1B5CE4A30B6556A71D0E574C7.description: Organizing Idea: Citizenship: Understanding local, national, and global issues empowers individual and collective action toward an inclusive society.

064C4B3DF66A48FE93E728B040ECDD9D.description: Identify the contributions made by a woman, or a group of women, to the fur trade.

67CB5437120D44FB9C9171F067BEDD2A.description: Discuss interactions between First Nations, Métis, and Europeans that occurred as part of the fur trade.

98E25A0499A0400A950A0B838B3A34B3.description: Model the fur trade’s system of exchange.

70BEABA0AF064A6AB5729BD020389F62.description: Trade can contribute to social and economic change.

338D154289D0441F80724D1843601A8F.description: Social and economic success of the fur trade relied on First Nations and Métis women, who were intermediaries between European traders and First Nations and Métis communities.

4ED218F3BB164AFD9C11DABB4BEF3B9F.description: Roles of First Nations, Métis, and Europeans that contributed to the fur trade included

7C80F82CB0464D3ABDAE44FDEBB205D7.description: warehouses for goods, supplies, and medicines

B1CE18AFE8FA49C78D488999090CF58C.description: centres for interactions such as meeting and bartering

DAC681D24D1A4EB19023A8CE4FBF6F79.description: expand farther north and west by building more trading posts and forts

23F160C822EB4F18A9A56204EFBB5CFA.description: establish the Hudson's Bay Company and the North West Company

8B6B5610B13F4901AEE83FD9ABAA4BA4.description: Competition for control of the fur trade motivated Europeans to

3283E883666541E3B871AD7DA44E46DD.description: Through the fur trade, furs were shipped from North America to Europe, where supply was low, and manufactured goods were shipped from Europe to North America, where demand was high.

8CA90A78871E40F6B36E8FC627DAAE29.description: Learning Outcome: Students examine the role of the fur trade in the development of Canada.

7C84A9C0D95E494EA718DEC6192A3A20.description: Describe the historical and modern significance of the British North America Act.

E8A67FDE1D7D4B27B2AE12DAAE5DD890.description: Examine perspectives of Francophones and Anglophones on Confederation.

F55DCA617D9E44BAA98E93F62D68034C.description: Discuss reasons for negotiations that led to Confederation.

B5FDC0E104F8427E965F21CE715850EE.description: The BNA Act established the parliamentary system with Members of Parliament (MPs) as representatives, the prime minister as the leader, and a Governor General to represent the Crown (the sovereign).

FFF05D26B518416BA82828262C4BB9B6.description: The BNA Act united the Province of Canada, which was renamed Ontario and Quebec, with New Brunswick and Nova Scotia to form the Dominion of Canada at Confederation in 1867.

D27D07D0D32344829BA457C1C30C7E65.description: The Fathers of Confederation, including Anglophone and Francophone politicians, contributed to the negotiation of the British North America Act (1867), which is also known as the BNA Act or the Constitution Act of 1867.

FD50F360896A45338C771C7CE4FD00DD.description: Negotiations involved debates about issues such as American expansionism and the construction of a railroad system.

16547D86C98945A1B34164CD526771F8.description: Negotiations between the British colonies and the British government about a possible union of the colonies took place over several years (Charlottetown Conference, Quebec Conference, London Conference).

2284EEC4D5C7406E91B207016DA521DD.description: The structure of government in Canada evolved over time, was shaped by historical events and acts, and reflects British governance.

F7E6BDC52C68471F80D33EB7A599970C.description: Learning Outcome: Students investigate historical influences on the federal government in Canada.

11F13A68B838419EAC5561B0D3A22813.description: Organizing Idea: Systems: Evaluating processes and structures of organizations builds understanding of decision making in the world.

7BD811C6984E4F9EA198DE8317ED3F03.description: Assess the relationship between home countries and colonies.

4417D7428F334131B0495B6F93E65641.description: Examine the challenges and contributions of immigrants before Confederation.

128BBB1C85B54B5C9540097803F3F4F8.description: Research French settlements in the land that is now known as the province of Quebec and explore the challenges in establishing settlements.

F1AFA7CE00E04FC9A25797D0D3779AB9.description: The establishment of New France began European colonization of Canada.

B6A8A6AED4DE40BA9A322B42E616F718.description: France and Britain imported natural resources from the colonies in North America, for example,

4F1C25E164624A0F91EAB519E77A5C07.description: Colonists brought belief systems and ways of organizing society to the colonies, including

1637179025EC4987AF9149D12A38D72B.description: Colonists came to the colonies for a variety of opportunities, for example,

85CFC57D64E541748EA1558F9A1285C2.description: Colonization involved European monarchs expanding empires by claiming land and establishing colonies on land already occupied by Indigenous peoples around the world, including in North America (imperialism).

7A1DA466660246D88C4F898EDFAB1762.description: France founded the colonies of Acadia, New France, and Louisiana, and Britain founded the Thirteen Colonies.

FA1DE69230D3410FA759943A049324B4.description: Samuel de Champlain, who established Quebec City, became the governor of New France and made alliances with the First Nations of the area.

A9626F4BEBDA4D47BD6947D9B6A38406.description: France established permanent settlements on the land now known as Canada, including

3FB3D3386F3940BA9273FE5A624E17FF.description: Learning Outcome: Students examine significant historical events that contributed to the formation of the country of Canada.

73C5C92A76A34A58AE65C57B7C6D03D1.description: Investigate stories about the Underground Railroad.

FCC5E196C5434A7F9AB17794A4637A75.description: Describe the role of the War of 1812 in building relationships between groups in the land now known as Canada.

0B8D005BCB464489A5431C8581B0F21E.description: Infer how migration influenced the balance of power in the land now known as Canada.

D2B87B9B56E64D7B8E9E05CDFF449DB5.description: Compare changes in political boundaries using maps of pre-Confederation Canada.

7F64D1D8AF0F4317BBA01E25B8AE16AA.description: Relate the Quebec Act to Francophone rights in Canada.

506A6CA7E94E41FD84562B10182C03B2.description: Discuss the significance of the Royal Proclamation for First Nations.

09706F0C8BB44E4489D436B39155FC3A.description: Describe the shift in control of colonies in the land now known as Canada.

1694ADA2A51142B29D925B8245B8706C.description: Investigate the travels of an explorer to the land now known as Canada.

A69AE270F52F49C9B8BEA7283ABE797A.description: Discuss ways relationships were built between First Nations and Europeans.

1234FD522B5142F89935A328392615BB.description: Compare reasons for exploration and establishing colonies around the world.

F096ABE8F1BD42A594887E3DEF6E5BDC.description: Governments can make changes in response to the actions of the population.

DBEE23B75B55459597FA7DDE05730584.description: Immigrants contributed to the foundation of Canada.

955CB37B95CE4C18AC029ED374037CC6.description: New acts and legislation set foundations for Canada.

2F847E45011843319A5A2E4B106EAB30.description: Wars, rivalries, and treaties in Europe disrupted life in the colonies.

C8A018629A2342CB9991D1DE2307E150.description: Dissatisfaction over the balance of power between Anglophones and Francophones led to rebellions in Upper and Lower Canada (1837–38) and the creation of the Province of Canada (Act of Union), including

1914707ABCA74F718D3112FD373760DA.description: After Britain abolished slavery (1833), enslaved Black people from the United States of America migrated to the land now known as Canada with the support of the Underground Railroad.

52AA4B8038434E25A9864E31788CFCAB.description: After the War of 1812, Britain encouraged people from England, Scotland, Wales, and Ireland to migrate to the land now known as Canada during what is called the Great Migration (1815–50).

63ADB214C62A4D969D914BFD16372A3C.description: British colonists, French colonists, First Nations, and Métis shared a common purpose of resisting American expansion in a series of battles over territory and trade in North America, known as the War of 1812.

3D4E50C9F1CF4511BFB5415B192342A5.description: In response to the increase of Loyalists, the Crown divided the province of Quebec into Upper Canada and Lower Canada (Constitution Act, 1791, Canada Act).

A40BCEC0B3F544CF9DCCF5621EE128DB.description: Loyalists from the Thirteen Colonies (United Empire Loyalists) migrated to colonies in the land now known as Canada.

E6DBC8A029754EB685439F04CB6E837C.description: After the United States of America became independent, a border with British North America was established (Treaty of Paris, 1783).

3AAAE4D409B941E1A6417A920E19DD90.description: The Thirteen Colonies gained independence from Britain (American Revolution) and established the United States of America (1776).

A98BAD7DA37C46D6AA910244EA146868.description: The Quebec Act (1774) recognized French language and religious rights in the province of Quebec and provided a foundation for bilingualism in Canada.

EF2C5B7CACB04F66B8CA4EE9449ABDA6.description: The Royal Proclamation and the Quebec Act impacted ways of living, including

D2E54592CE17422ABB68FDBF13EB1C8D.description: The Royal Proclamation and the Quebec Act impacted ways of living for

D9733C185CBC48A5A23FF9795424E640.description: establishment of First Nations relations to the Crown

63295AC5FEB144E7BE42A269E4742F4B.description: establishment of nation-to-nation treaty making process

519626E461E4491F86D36FACEB81EBD0.description: recognition of First Nations right to self-government

392953CBAAAD4D239693CAF7817F8C99.description: recognition of First Nations as the original inhabitants of North America

D9E15324496A4E6AA5A344018041796B.description: The Royal Proclamation (1763) has ongoing significance for First Nations today, including

0D743A24D7504F719021A626796B7B60.description: Acts were passed by the British to rule and organize colonies in North America.

A27A8210DBB74A34BD9BF9D70BA63670.description: French colonists remained on the lands known as Acadia and New France after Britain gained control of the territories.

D0AF36D8199A476EA9427C9668439F6E.description: Britain gained control of Acadia (Treaty of Utrecht, 1713) and New France (Treaty of Paris, 1763) as the result of treaties signed between Britain and France.

4039FA76FE3C479FBC2D9D53C97938D2.description: Colonies were transferred from France to Britain as a result of conflicts and treaties.

663C642DAAF8416380478FBB6EB7EE22.description: First Nations and Europeans made treaties with each other, such as the Two Row Wampum (Gaswéñdah), to start a relationship of living side by side.

D91D243C711C4C74A1858F5E447E35F6.description: To gain territories, resources, and prestige (expansionism), European countries sent explorers overseas, for example,

A210153DA4D441F3B4FAAAAF6771AC42.description: Learning Outcome: Students investigate changes in Canada’s political boundaries.

CC6CB7B284C943609C3B7D73D38A65A4.description: Organizing Idea: Time and Place: Exploring the dynamic relationships between people, place, and time supports understanding of perspectives and events to make meaning of the world.
